plants.name: Rosa spp.
plants.description: Roses are woody perennial flowering plants known for their large, often fragrant flowers. They bloom widely during late spring and summer and can be found in many varieties worldwide.
plants.bloomingSeason: May to July (northern hemisphere) and November to January (southern hemisphere)
plants.funFact: Roses have been symbols of love and beauty for centuries, and there are over 300 species and thousands of cultivars worldwide.

plants.name: Lupinus polyphyllus
plants.description: A perennial wildflower with tall spikes of pea-like flowers, often seen in wild or cultivated settings. It blooms in late spring and early summer.
plants.location: Western North America, cultivated in temperate gardens
plants.funFact: Lupines enrich soil by fixing nitrogen with symbiotic bacteria in their roots, benefiting the surrounding plants.

plants.name: Nymphaea spp.
plants.description: Aquatic plants rooted in soil in bodies of water, displaying large floating leaves and attractive blossoms that open during the day.
plants.location: Worldwide in temperate and tropical climates
plants.funFact: Many water lily species have flowers that open in early morning and close by afternoon, repeating this cycle for several days.

plants.name: Eucalyptus globulus
plants.description: A fast-growing evergreen tree native to Australia, known for its peeling bark and clusters of white flowers that bloom in late spring to mid-summer.
plants.bloomingSeason: October to January (Southern Hemisphere), can bloom variably in other regions
plants.location: Native to southeastern Australia, also cultivated worldwide
plants.funFact: Blue Gum eucalyptus produces eucalyptus oil used in medicinal and industrial applications, known for its strong scent.
